Award.AwardTitle: Collaborative Research: Understanding Cholesteric Pitch in Nanocylinder Films

Division.LongName: Div Of Chem, Bioeng, Env, & Transp Sys

Award.AbstractNarration:
CBET 1436637/1437073
Liquid crystals are material phases that exhibit both crystalline order and the fluidity of a liquid. This project will investigate the properties of nanocylinder dispersions that can form liquid crystals. The particular liquid crystals being investigated are termed cholesteric (chiral) because the nanocylinders align in a preferred direction, but the preferred direction itself rotates about an axis. As a result of this structure, cholesteric liquid crystals can have unusual optical properties. When the materials are processed into thin films, the unusual structure and optical properties are maintained, which makes the materials especially interesting for applications such as liquid crystal displays, decorative coatings, and specialty inks. This project will investigate the rheological properties of nanocylinder dispersions and analyze how flow changes the microstructural characteristics and optical properties of the materials when processed into thin films. The results will help scientists and engineers to design and process cholesteric liquid crystals into films with controlled optical properties.

A combination of experiments and modeling will be used to understand the effects of dispersion properties and flow on dispersion rheological and morphological properties. This will result in parameter space maps for the dispersion rheology and microstructure as a function of composition and shear rate. Two model systems capable of forming lyotropic cholesteric liquid crystals will be investigated: aqueous dispersions of sulfonated cellulose nanocrystals and aqueous dispersions of double stranded DNA and single-walled carbon nanotubes. For both systems, a combination of mesoscopic polydomain modeling techniques and physical experiments will be used to investigate the following features: 1) the microstructure (texture) as a function of mesogen concentration as probed by oscillatory rheology, 2) transients during the start-up of steady shear, 3) the steady shear rheological behavior, particularly at low shear, 4) texture at rest and texture development after flow cessation, and 5) texture and optical properties of solidified films.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Many people have admired iridescence brilliant colors in nature. However, few people realize that these colors can be the result of nanoscale helical ordering in the organism's outer layers. For example, beetles' iridescent colors are related to the helical, or chiral, ordering of chitin. The helical pitch determines the wavelength of maximum reflection and the observed color. This research was focused on understanding how to controllably produce similar structures from dispersions of a natural material known as cellulose nanocrystals. Cellulose nanocrystals are tiny building blocks that can be extracted from biomass including plants and trees. They have outstanding mechanical properties, and the type used in this research can be easily dispersed in water to form chiral liquid crystal phases. Similar to the chitin in beetles, these phases can result in the selective reflection of light. However, processing chiral nematic dispersions into solid materials with controlled optical properties requires understanding the complex interrelated effects of dispersion microstructure, processing shear, substrate interactions, and drying.

This research used a combination of physical experiments and modeling to gain new insights into the microstructure and processing of chiral nematic phases. It focused on materials made from sulfated cellulose nanocrystals extracted from woody biomass. The research used reflected cross-polarized spectroscopy and rheology combined with cross-polarized optical microscopy or small angle neutron scattering (SANS) to gain insights into the effects of concentration, shear, and post-shear relaxation on cellulose nanocrystal alignment. It also provided new understanding of the combined effects of concentration, surface anchoring, and evaporation rate on the orientation, helical pitch, and optical properties of films produced from the cellulose nanocrystal dispersions. Collaboration with Dr. Micah Green's group at Texas A&M University resulted in the development of models which qualitatively captured key experimental results and will enable extension of the findings to other systems.

In addition to advancing the understanding needed to produce advanced biomimetic optical materials from sustainable nanoscale building blocks, this research increased American competitiveness through the training of four undergraduate and four graduate students. The findings from the research have been presented at numerous conferences and resulted in four publications and numerous presentations. The colorful images resulting from the award have facilitated science communication, and one of the articles was featured on the cover of ACS Applied Nanomaterials. During the award, the PI and students also engaged in numerous outreach activities aimed at increasing the diversity of K-12 students that plan to pursue STEM pathways.
